My Resume

William V. Schutz Jr, PhD, MPH, MSW

Email: wschutz01@gmail.com

Mobile Phone: 703 609-6947

Personal Information

I have a physical disability. I am a wheelchair user and also walk with Canadian crutches due to cerebral palsy. I speak and write fluent French and Spanish. I also speak and write Portuguese I grew up in Canada and the Miami Florida area. I believe that the provision of reliable, accurate, and usable information is the gateway to personal choice while the lack of it is the gateway to personal chains. Two of my favorite quotes are One of my favorite sayings comes from Theodore Roosevelt.

Professional Summary

Through my work experience, formal education, and personal commitment to life-long learning, I have developed an eclectic skill set drawn from the fields social science, social work, public policy, public health, health information, library science, information technology and foreign languages.

For over thirty years, I have used this eclectic skill set to improve the missions, services and products, and human capital skill sets of disability and social service organizations in both the private and public sectors. Looking at organizations I have worked for and the roles I have occupied in them, several key themes are prevalent in my career. These include but are not limited to:

  • Helping stakeholders (researchers, clinicians, engineers, consumer advocates, family members and individuals with disabilities) solve problems they care about by connecting them to relevant people, organizations, processes, information, and resources;

  • Analyzing data and creating “reader-friendly products for various target audiences;

  • Transforming data into actionable information so various stakeholders can use it to make whatever matters to them better;

  • Designing and developing better knowledge management systems

  • Improving the accessibility and usability of information technology systems and software products

  • Building capacity in others through teaching mentorship; and,

  • Improving communication and understanding among different cultural groups or members of disenfranchised populations and majority groups.

Research Interests

  • Quantitative and qualitative program evaluation methods

  • Program implementation and performance measurement

  • Disability studies especially pertaining to:
    • Assessing and fulfilling the diverse information needs of various constituent groups (e.g., persons with disabilities and their family members, organizations serving persons with disabilities) within the rehabilitation /disability community
    • The impact of managed care
    • Funding mechanisms related to the provision of assistive devices and services
    • Policy analysis
    • Multiculturalism and social oppression
    • The use of computers and the Internet as resource identification and information dissemination tools
    • State systems’ change efforts especially related to Traumatic Brain Injury (TBI)

  • Accessibility and usability of information technology systems and software for all users with a special focus on assistive technology users.

  • Knowledge Translation

  • Science Communication

  • Aging and Cerebral Palsy

Work Experience

2014 to Present

Chief Data Officer, National Institute on Disability Independent Living and Rehabilitation Research (NIDILRR)

  • Improved accessibility and usability outcomes of the Administration for Community Living’s Office of Information Resources Management by performing tasks including but not limited to:
    • Testing ITIO configurations and pushes in regards to Accessibility to help reduce negative impacts to ACL users;
    • Pilot testing machines, operating systems, Microsoft Office versions, and other software to identify incompatibilities with Assistive Technology and the user experience
    • Evaluating various assistive technology tools such as but not limited to JAWS, NVDA Screen Reader, Windows Magnifier, Zoom Text, etc
    • Working to help identify technical solutions to address assistive technology issues such as the ability to retain user customized settings which will help save time and money
    • Maintaining a repository on the share drive for accessibility tips, keyboard short cuts, and other resources related to accessibility
    • Performing accessibility testing on ACL developed systems and applications
    • Assisting with the identification of accessibility issues throughout ACL in order for OIRM to help understand and prioritize requirements and issues
    • Serving as the technical liaison for NIDILRR with OIRM
  • Increased NIDILRR’s Director’s understanding of staff and agency information-technology needs and tools by
    • Conducting bi-weekly informational, brainstorming, and/or IT learning sessions via WebEx;
    • Drafting documents on topics related to information technology and knowledge management;
    • Interviewing NIDILRR staff about knowledge gaps and problems they experience while using agency-provided information technology systems and software;
    • Developing and implementing a broad set of recommendations and specifications to shape NIDILRR’s current and future knowledge management initiatives.
  • Improved the quality of NIDILRR agency data by
    • Developing and running various queries and algorithims designed to identify duplicate or erroneously-entered data;
    • Developing guidelines for grantees on how data should be entered into the agency web-based annual and final performance reporting system;
    • Content-analyzing the questions/items in our web-based reporting system to ensure that grantee-responses to them yield the data the agency needs.
    • Sharing my technical expertise with the NIDILRR agency-wide data group.
  • Improved staff access to, and use of, agency data by
    • Creating an annual repository of grantee accomplishments on the agency shared network drive
    • Identifying requirements, and making recommendations, for the development of various web portals, for use by NIDILRR staff, ACL staff, U.S. Department of Health and Human Services staff, and external stakeholders.
    • Developing ad-hoc customized queries and reports designed to meet the information needs of NIDILRR and ACL staff, and external stakeholders.
  • Improved staff capacity to identify and use grantee-produced research, development, and training outputs and outcomes by
    • Querying, extracting, cleaning and summarizing data from various agency data sources including the Web-based grantee annual and final performance reporting system.
    • Producing usable and actionable output and outcome reports in Word format sorted by Project Officer, Program, or other user-specified criteria.
  • Increased staff information technology literacy by delivering easy-to-understand instructions via multiple dissemination methods including but not limited to:
    • one-one-one technical assistance sessions;
    • WebEx technical assistance sessions;
    • Email messages and newsletters
    • Short closed-captioned videos;
    • Written documentation; and
    • web pages and Wikis.
  • Saved staff time and effort by improving agency workflow and document production processes by

2002 to 2013

Rehabilitation Program Specialist, National Institute on Disability and Rehabilitation Research, Office of Special Education and Rehabilitation Research, U.S. Department of Education

  • Improved NIDRR-grantee understanding of performance management by:
    • Facilitating a grantee and agency mind-set change from an exclusive focus on the conduct of research and development activities to a focus on results, including outputs and outcomes.
    • Conducting group and one-on-one grantee orientation and training teleconferences on the language of performance management and the development of research and development logic models and other outcome-oriented documents;
    • Explaining performance management concepts, including logic models, to attendees at grantee state-of-science conferences.
    • Developing various training materials, including templates for briefing books, to be completed by NIDRR-funded grantees

Community Services

1984-1985

Creator and Participant in Swimathon to Benefit United Cerebral Palsy of Miami

Back in 1984, I was an undergraduate student at the University of Miami. I wanted to give back and make a difference to a cause I cared about–United Cerebral Palsy. My reason for caring was personal as I have cerebral palsy. I also loved swimming and used to swim at the University of Miami daily. My close friend and college suite-mate, Sheik Baksh, worked with me to leverage, mobilize, and coordinate resources to make the Swim-a-thon. an event that was part of Homecoming. I swam 300 laps and raised money, along with numerous other pledgers, including members of the UM swim team. The event was very successful and raised $3000-4000 in 1984 and $8000 in 1985.

1980-1982

Creator and Manager of a Food and Clothing Drive for Haitian and Cuban Refugees in Miami

All throughout my time in high school I had an interest in helping those less fortunate, especially immigrants. I was also studying French and Spanish and wanted to use my linguistic skills to serve and support under-represented groups in my community. So I encouraged students at my school to donate clothes, food and other supplies to the Haitian and Cuban refugee camps in Miami. I set up donation bins in school and at breaks, I asked my parents to drive me down to the the Haitian and Cuban refugee camps. I spoke both the leaders of these camps and temporary residents of these camps. These individuals expressed their profound gratitude for my efforts as the donations I collected helped new refugees get a “fresh start” in their new country.

Awards and Professional Affiliations

2000

Pennsylvania Office of Vocational Rehabilitation Client of the Year

Of all the clients served in the state of Pennsylvania, I was named the client of the year. by this state agency.

1999

Scientific Peer Reviewer, National Institute on Disability and Rehabilitation Research, Office of Special Education and Rehabilitation Reseearch, U.S. Department of Education.

The National Institute on Disability and Rehabilitation Research always needs qualified peer reviewers to review applications. Without peer reviewers to review, evaluate, and score the applications received by the agency, NIDILRR would not be able to perform its federal grants-making function. I was asked to serve as a peer reviewer because I have the scientific expertise necessary to evaluate the rigor of the methods proposed in applications. I also have personal experience as a person with a disability so I am also able to evaluate the relevance of the ideas articulated in the submitted applications.

1996

Plaque of Appreciation for Service to the National Rehabilitation Information Center, a federal government contract operated by the KRA corporation for the National Institute on Disability and Rehabilitation Research, Office of Special Education and Rehabilitation Services, U.S. Department of Education.

In my role six-year role as public inquiry services manager at the National Rehabilitation Information Center (NARIC), I was awarded this plaque as recognition for all of the leadership, guidance, expertise, services, and resources I provided to the staff and the numerous patrons served by it.

1995

Recipient of the first KRA Corporation Community Service Award

I was fortunate to be the first recipient of the company’s inaugural community service award. I received it for all of my continued work as a proctor/mentor for graduate students in the community over the years. I

1993

Scientific Peer Reviewer, National Institute on Disability and Rehabilitation Research, Office of Special Education and Rehabilitation Reseearch, U.S. Department of Education.

The National Institute on Disability and Rehabilitation Research always needs qualified peer reviewers to review applications. Without peer reviewers to review, evaluate, and score the applications received by the agency, NIDILRR would not be able to perform its federal grants-making function. I was asked to serve as a peer reviewer because I have the scientific expertise necessary to evaluate the rigor of the methods proposed in applications. I also have personal experience as a person with a disability so I am also able to evaluate the relevance of the ideas articulated in the submitted applications.

Distinguished Rehabilitation Manpower Service Award for Mid-Atlantic Region III of the National Rehabilitation Association

As a result of my work at the National Institute on Disability and Rehabilitation Research, my efforts to mentor young rehabilitation professionals,and my efforts to increase rehabilitation training and education opportunities, I was fortunate enough to receive the Rehabilitation Manpower Service award for the Mid-Atlantic Region.

1989

Member, National Association of Social Work

I was a member of the National Association of Social Work. I still adhere to the National Association of Social Work’s Code of Ethics.

I was a member of this organization when I was a master’s degree student.

Life-time member Alpha Delta Mu (National Honor Society in Social Work)

Based on my excellent academic performance during my Master’s degree program in social work, I was invited to join this national honor society in social work.
